cell.color:
Class: Cartilaginous Fishes (Chondrichthyes)
Order: Myliobatiformes
Family: Mobulidae
Genus: Manta
Species: Devil Ray
The Atlantic Devil Ray occurs in coastal waters, reef areas, and also breakwaters.
The Devil Ray generally stays in waters with temperatures of 75-77 degrees
The Atlantic Devil Ray occurs almost exclusively on the American coast, however, there are a couple of groups that have been recorded in Africa

text.cell:
The Atlantic Devil Ray is available as soon as your zoo gains a fame rating of: 1/2 stars.
Description:
Taxonomy
The Atlantic devil ray was described in 1831 by Bancroft as Cephalopterus hypostomus. The scientific name for this ray was later changed to Mobula hypostoma (Bancroft 1831). Synonyms include Mobula olfersii and Cephaloptera olfersii M�ller 1834, Cephaloptera massenoidea, Hill 1862, and Ceratobatis robertsi, Ceratobatic robertsii, and Mobula reobertsi, Boulanger 1897.
Common Names
The name of the Atlantic devil ray comes from the ray's distinctive "horns" formed by the forward facing cephalic fins. It is also known as the lesser devil ray (English), devil ray (English), small devilfish (English), atlantische duivelsrog (Dutch), diable g�ant (French), mante diable (French), diablo (Portuguese), jamanta (Portuguese), manta chica (Spanish), manta enana (Spanish), raya (Spanish), and vestatlantisk djaevlerokke (Danish). The Atlantic devil ray is often confused with its larger family member, Manta birostris, and in many languages the common names appear interchangeable.
Geographical Distribution
The Atlantic devil ray can be found in the western Atlantic Ocean from North Carolina south to northern Argentina. Sightings are common along the Atlantic coast of Florida and the surrounding areas (particularly in the summer), as well as in the Gulf of Mexico and in the Antilles. This ray is known to inhabit tropical waters between 24-25� south and 34-35� north latitude. Unconfirmed reports suggest M. hypostoma may stray as far north as New Jersey, west to the eastern Atlantic coast, and south to the coast of Senegal, Africa, but these specimens may be misidentified M. mobular or Manta birostris.
Content provided courtesy of http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/Gallery/Descript/AtlanticDevilRay/AtlanticDevilRay.htmlCoding by Dennis1991 and Skinning by Nique!
